awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Testing for genes associated with migratory behavior in a peripatetic species
awd_abstract_narration:
Significant ecological changes are expected over the next century, including substantial increases in sea level, annual precipitation, daily temperature, spread of invasive species, and urbanization. To survive these changes, species will be required to either adapt to new conditions or move (disperse) to suitable habitats. Many species are unable to disperse due to geographic, physiological or social constraints, while other species disperse broadly and often. Peripatetic species are migrant in that they are based in various locations for relatively short periods of time. It is frequently assumed that these highly mobile species will weather large-scale habitat disturbance via dispersal. This assumption, however, has rarely been tested and there is little known of the genetic basis of migration in peripatetic species, which is key to determining the likelihood of dispersal and colonization of new habitats. This research will shed light on the evolutionary responses of a peripatetic species to the drastic environmental changes expected over the next century. At the same time, it will improve our understanding of evolution and behavior of wading birds generally and provide the information needed to properly focus conservation management efforts. This project also will support the development of a bioinformatics course and the training of a postdoctoral fellow.

This study uses the threatened American wood stork (Mycteria americana) as a model species to study the evolution of migratory behavior in peripatetic species. A complete and annotated reference genome will be built for wood storks. Whole genome resequencing and genome-wide association analysis will be used to test for genes under positive selection between resident and migrant storks nesting throughout the US southeast and Cuba. The project will test if variation at migration candidate genes is correlated with recent colonization of stork nesting sites and allow for surveys of variation at these genes in wading birds broadly. The study will reveal the evolutionary origins and  genetic architecture of migratory phenotypes in wood storks with broad implications for the evolution of behavior.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2021, the Ramstad Lab at the University of South Carolina Aiken received a $199,926 EAGER award entitled ‘Testing for genes associated with migratory behavior in a peripatetic species.’ The primary goal of the project was to test for genes associated with different migratory behaviors observed in species that are peripatetic, meaning that they travel from place to place or are based in various places for relatively short periods of time. We used the wood stork (Mycteria americana; WOST) as a model species to test for genes associated with migration, and the assumption that peripatetic species are likely to survive the environmental changes forecast for the next century by simply changing their location and/or migratory behavior.

 

The study system

Wood storks are large colonially nesting wading birds that reside in wetlands of the southeastern US, Mexico, Central and South America, and the Caribbean. WOST rely on the regular ebb and flow of water levels in their wetland habitat; they must nest above open water, but need shallow water to feed. Migrant WOST move seasonally between distant nesting and foraging sites, resident birds stay in the same area to nest and feed throughout the year, and some individuals are facultative migrants, moving between nesting and feeding sites in some years but not others. There is little known of the genetic basis of migration in wading birds. If there are specific genes associated with migratory behavior in WOST, then survival of individuals will rely on birds having variants of those genes that promote or allow migration. Further, the pattern of variation at these ‘migration genes’ across nesting colonies would determine which colonies will persist and the resiliency of the species as a whole.

 

A new reference genome 

We developed the first reference genome for WOST, which is 1.35Gb in length and highly contiguous (with only 5 scaffolds including at least half of the full assembly). The reference genome is also highly complete, with 98.8% recovery of core orthologs (genes present in different species that evolved from a common ancestral gene and serve the same function). The reference is fully annotated, with the location of individual genes and other features of the genome, and their functions, identified.

Our work uncovered genomic arrangements that are unique to storks and highlighted the difficulty associated with delineating microchromosomes in reference genome assemblies. This new reference genome is entirely available publicly, provides a foundation for studying genomic evolution in the core water bird clade (penguins, albatrosses, storks, cormorants, herons, and ibises) and will allow for numerous genomic studies that will aid in wood stork conservation.

 

Genomic basis of stork migration behavior 

We developed a bioinformatic pipeline to perform genome-wide association analyses and identify candidate genes associated with binary phenotypic variation. We then performed a GWAS of 130 wood storks from colonies classified as either primarily migratory or primarily resident (4 colonies each).

Our analysis did not reveal any strong signals of specific genomic regions associated with migratory behavior in wood storks. No sites within the genome were significantly differentiated between migrant and resident colonies at our most stringent significance threshold. At a relaxed significance threshold, 41 sites on 18 chromosomes were moderately associated with migratory behavior. Our results suggest that migratory behavior has a genetic basis in wood storks but involves many genes that each contribute a small amount to the overall determination of whether a stork is migratory or resident.

This pattern also suggests that migratory behavior may be highly plastic and strongly influenced by environmental factors. Many of the colonies that exhibit residency are also found in urban areas. These colonies differ from those in natural and wild habitats in that they offer year-round food availability at or near nesting sites. A similar behavioral shift has been recently observed among white storks (Ciconia ciconia) in Portugal where storks have taken up residency at land fill sites.

 

Broader Impacts

Specific products and outcomes from this project. 

  • A high quality annotated WOST reference genome that is assembled at the chromosomal level and fully annotated.
  • A robust and reliable bioinformatics pipeline for GWAS analysis.
  • Nine presentations at scientific conferences, wood stork management meetings, and for the public.
  • One manuscript in review and two more in preparation.
  • Three undergraduate students trained in genomics, bioinformatics, scientific presentation and grant writing via independent capstone research.
  • One Postdoctoral Fellow provided teaching, research and undergraduate mentoring experience.
  • A Bioinformatics Workshop on genome-wide association analysis provided for fourteen students, staff and faculty from three universities.
  • Bioinformatic lab activities developed for an undergraduate course in Applied Population Genomics (BIOLA352) at USC Aiken.
  • A broad and public resource for learning basic bioinformatics and running GWAS analyses available on GitHub (https://github.com/rflamio/usca-bioinfo-wk).
